sections.title: Overview of the Closing Phase
sections.markdown:
## 8.1 Overview of the Closing Phase

The final phase of a PM² project is the Closing Phase. The Closing Phase starts with the Project-End Review Meeting and ends with the Project Owner’s (PO) final approval, which marks the project’s administrative closure. During the Closing Phase, the project’s activities are completed, the project’s final state is documented, and the finished deliverables are officially transferred to the Project Owner (PO).

![](/pm2/figures/fig-8-1.png)

**Fig 8.1** Closing Phase activities and main outputs

### Artefacts

- Ready for Closing (RfC)
- Project-End Review Agenda / MoM
- Project-End Report
  - Lessons Learned
  - Best Practices
  - Post-Project Recommendations
- Project Acceptance Note

**Fig 8.2** Closing Phase artefacts

sections.title: Project-End Review Meeting
sections.markdown:
## 8.2 Project-End Review Meeting

The Closing Phase starts with an official Project-End Review Meeting. Project performance is discussed, team and contractor performance are evaluated, and Lessons Learned are captured.

### **Key Participants**

- **Project Manager (PM):** Organises the meeting.
- **Project Core Team (PCT):** Attendance is required.
- **Project Owner (PO):** Attendance is required.
- **Project Quality Assurance (PQA):** Should attend.
- **Business Manager (BM):** Represents the business side and stakeholders.
- **Other stakeholders:** Optional but often valuable.

### **Inputs**
- Business Case and Project Charter
- Project Handbook and Project Work Plan
- All Project Plans (esp. Transition & Business Implementation Plans)
- Relevant Project Reports and Logs

### **Before the Meeting**
1. Plan the meeting and prepare the agenda.
2. Send the agenda in advance.
3. Prepare supporting material.
4. Confirm attendance.

### **During the Meeting**
1. PO expresses organisational appreciation.
2. Assign a minute-taker.
3. Present project statistics.
4. Discuss overall project experience.
5. Review challenges and how they were addressed.
6. Capture Lessons Learned and Best Practices.

### **After the Meeting**
1. Compile Lessons Learned and recommendations.
2. Produce the Project-End Report.
3. Communicate results to relevant stakeholders.

![](/pm2/figures/fig-8-3.png)

**Fig 8.3** Project-End Review Meeting inputs/outputs and main roles

### **Outputs**
- Project-End Review Minutes (MoM) ☑

sections.title: Lessons Learned and Post-Project Recommendations
sections.markdown:
## 8.3 Lessons Learned and Post-Project Recommendations

The purpose of formal Lessons Learned and Post-Project Recommendations is to ensure that the organisation benefits from the experience gained during the project. It is also the place to capture ideas for post-project work, extensions, maintenance, or follow-up projects.

**Note:** Improvement opportunities and recommendations should be captured as they arise during the project—otherwise they risk being forgotten by the time the project reaches the Closing Phase.

### **Key Participants**
- **Project Manager (PM):** Organises the lessons-learned activities.
- **Project Core Team (PCT):** Contributes insights and perspectives.
- **Business Manager (BM):** Provides the requestor/business perspective.
- **Other stakeholders:** Optional contributors, depending on context.

### **Guidelines**
- Conduct the Lessons Learned session during the Project-End Review Meeting (or separately if needed).
- If possible, have the session facilitated by someone independent of day-to-day project work.
- Use a structured format (phases, categories, themes) so no area is missed.
- Consider surveys or interviews to reach a broader stakeholder group.
- Organise improvement ideas into meaningful groups.
- Multiple sessions may be useful for large or complex projects.
- Invite the Project Steering Committee (PSC) to support organisational learning.

### **Outputs**
- Lessons Learned (consolidated)
- Post-Project Recommendations
- Inputs to the Project-End Report

sections.title: Project-End Report
sections.markdown:
## 8.4 Project-End Report

Following the Project-End Review Meeting, the Project-End Report summarises the entire project experience. It documents successes, pitfalls, Lessons Learned, Best Practices and practical recommendations for future projects.

### **Key Participants**
- **Project Manager (PM):** Writes the report.
- **Project Quality Assurance (PQA):** Provides review and input.
- **Project Core Team (PCT):** Contributes insights and clarifications.

### **Inputs**
- Project-End Review Minutes (MoM)
- Project Reports (Status/Progress/Quality)
- MoMs from earlier project meetings
- Quality Assurance & Control outputs

### **Guidelines**
The report should address:
- Project effectiveness
- Cost, schedule, scope and quality performance
- Risk management
- Issue management
- Project change management
- Communications management
- Human resources and stakeholder management
- Deliverables acceptance
- Business implementation & transition
- Performance of the PCT and provider/requestor organisations
- Best Practices
- Lessons Learned
- Post-Project Recommendations

The Project-End Report should become part of the organisation’s long-term knowledge base.

### **Outputs**
- Project-End Report ☑

sections.title: Administrative Closure
sections.markdown:
## 8.5 Administrative Closure

Administrative Closure finalises the project and formally transitions responsibilities, documentation, and deliverables to the Project Owner (PO). Once closure is complete, the project team is released and the project moves out of project mode.

### **Key Participants**
- **Project Manager (PM):** Oversees all closure activities and ensures resources are released.
- **Project Support Office (PSO):** Reviews, organises and archives all documentation.
- **Project Owner (PO):** Gives final approval and formally closes the project.
- **Other stakeholders:** Approve/accept the final deliverables.

### **Inputs**
- Project Handbook
- Project Work Plan
- Quality Management Plan
- All other project documents and logs

### **Steps**
1. Review, organise and archive all documentation.
2. Release all project resources.
3. Ensure all deliverables have been accepted by appropriate stakeholders.
4. Obtain final project approval from the Project Owner (PO).
5. Confirm that all contractual obligations have been fully met.

### **Outputs**
- Updated Project Archive
- Project Acceptance Note (if required)
